comments.raw_text:
** The problem **

Many websites are not accessible for keyboard users because the focus is hidden. As soon as the user begins to tab through they are already lost.

** Examples **

- http://blackberry.com
- http://www.apple.com/search/?q=iphone (search page)
- http://www.microsoft.com/windowsphone/en-us/default.aspx (Microsoft's Windows Phone 7 page)
- http://twitter.com (in the header)

** Background **

There are two main reasons that websites do this:
1. They use a standard reset.css which has :focus {outline: 0; } -- since many developers are primarily mouse users this can go unnoticed
2. The designer of the page does not like the focus outline to appear on buttons and links when a user simply clicks them (they don't mind the focus outline when the user tabs -- that's not the case they care about).

(Note: IE (at least older versions) do not allow the focus outline to be hidden and don't show the problem.)

** Proposed solution **

When the focus was not set from the mouse (keyboard or via script), do not allow the focus outline to be hidden.

Just because the author specifies something in CSS does not mean we have to adhere to it. There is a tradition of removing web usability problems such as popups, even when the author has coded the page to have them -- making the web not suck.

In this case, the web is sucking for keyboard users. There is really no reason to hide the focus for someone trying to tab around.

Some section 508 fodder if that helps:
From http://section508.gov/index.cfm?fuseAction=stdsdoc
(c) A well-defined on-screen indication of the current focus shall be provided that moves among interactive interface elements as the input focus changes.

>> I think we should start with it as a pref, get it landed
>> pref-ed off, and then decide what the default should be while sighted users
>> can already start to take advantage of it by opting-in.

David, did you mean a hidden pref so that people can test with it and give us feedback before we eventually turn it on permanently?

> Maybe the pref is not what we should do since it's hard discoverable (though > that's better than noting). If CSS doesn't adress this then spec 508 should 
> be enough to do this. Also this can be marked as parity with IE.

As long as the goal is to eventually turn it on permanently I'd say it's fine to do it in stages.

FWIW, I don't know what newer versions of IE do. This may have simply been a limitation of their :focus CSS capabilities.

> > 2. The designer of the page does not like the focus outline to appear on
> > buttons and links when a user simply clicks them (they don't mind the focus
> > outline when the user tabs -- that's not the case they care about).

> What mechanism do they use? Permanent CSS outline?

They usually use *:focus { outline : 0 }

> Firefox itself doesn't show outline when user clicks buttons but shows it when > it's tabbed. That's not what you talk about, right?

You're right, but we show the outline when a user clicks a link. I see that Chrome does not. So another part of this fix could be to stop showing the focus outline for link clicks, at least where there is an href. We should look at what Chrome's exact rule is. In any case that won't stop web developers from doing this so we would still need the keyboard/script always-show-focus rule.

comments.text: Focus indicators on non-native widgets are specified with the css outline property. To implement this you'd either need to somehow add a rule with a higher specificity, or simply draw the focus outline manually by calling nsCSSRendering::PaintOutline or something like that. I don't know much about the feasibillity of either, nor whether there is a better approach. You'd be best to ask dbaron about it.
